description: Originally a nautical term, possibly from French lâcher (“to let go”).

examples: the lurch of a ship, or of a drunkard

verbs.description: lurch (third-person singular simple present lurches, present participle lurching, simple past and past participle lurched)

entries.meaning: To make such a sudden, unsteady movement.

verbs.description: lurch (third-person singular simple present lurches, present participle lurching, simple past and past participle lurched)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To swallow or eat greedily; to devour; hence, to swallow up.

description: From Middle English *lurche (implied in derivative lurching), from Old French lourche (“deceived, embarrassed; also the name of a game”), from Proto-West Germanic *lort (“left; left-handed; crooked; bent; warped; underhanded; deceitful; limping”). Cognate to English lirt.

entries.meaning: An old game played with dice and counters; a variety of the game of tables.
A double score in cribbage for the winner when his/her adversary has not yet pegged his/her 31st hole.
examples: Lady Blandford has cried her eyes out on losing a lurch.

verbs.description: lurch (third-person singular simple present lurches, present participle lurching, simple past and past participle lurched)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To leave someone in the lurch; to cheat.
(obsolete, intransitive) To evade by stooping; to lurk.
(transitive) To defeat in the game of cribbage with a lurch (double score as explained under noun entry).
